definitions.definition: the short, thick finger at the side of the hand, slightly apart from the other four

examples.text: She still **sucks her thumb** when she's worried.
He smiled and raised a thumb in greeting.
I picked up the beetle carefully between finger and thumb.
I stuck out a thumb and a car stopped immediately.

definitions.definition: the part of a glove that covers the thumb

examples.text: There's a hole in the thumb.

definitions.definition: to be awkward with your hands so that you drop things or are unable to do something
to hope that your plans will be successful or that something will take place in the way that you want it to

examples.text: Let's hold thumbs that you get the job.

definitions.definition: a practical method of doing or measuring something, usually based on past experience rather than on exact measurement

examples.text: As a rule of thumb, you should cook a chicken for 20 minutes for each pound of weight.

definitions.definition: to be very easy to notice in an unpleasant way

examples.text: The blue building stood out like a sore thumb among the whitewashed villas.
If you wear a suit to the party, you’ll stand out like a sore thumb.

definitions.definition: used to show that something has been accepted/rejected or that it is/is not a success

examples.text: Their proposals **were given the thumbs down**.
It looks like it's thumbs up for their latest album.
He made a thumbs-up sign through the window to tell us everything was fine.

definitions.definition: to move your thumbs around each other with your fingers joined together
to do nothing while you are waiting for something to happen

examples.text: We can't just sit here twiddling our thumbs and hoping everything will be all right.
She’s got him under her thumb.

wordOrigin: Old English thūma, of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch duim and German Daumen, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin tumere ‘to swell’. The verb dates from the late 16th cent., first in the sense ‘play (a musical instrument) with the thumbs’.
